alerts.title: Permanent fire prohibition on Teewah Beach
alerts.description: A QPWS imposed fire prohibition is in place in the Cooloola Recreation Area, except at Poverty Point camping area. Campfires must not be lit anywhere else in the recreation area including in the Teewah Beach camping zones 1-7.
alerts.details:
A QPWS imposed fire prohibition is in place in the Cooloola Recreation Area, except at Poverty Point camping area. Campfires must not be lit anywhere else in the recreation area including in the Teewah Beach camping zones 1-7.

This permanent fire prohibition was implemented to reduce the risk of bushfires, protect critical habitat of native wildlife, enhance visitor safety from campfire related injuries and reduce rubbish from non-combustible materials being burnt.

Fully enclosed cooking and heating appliances can still be used in camping areas that meet the below requirements.

  • The appliance must use gas or manufactured fuel (heat beads, briquettes). Manufactured fuel does not include timber or wood.
  • It must be used only for cooking and/or heating.
  • It must be a minimum of 20cm off the ground and more than 2m from flammable materials, which includes vegetation. 
  • It must not have the potential to generate airborne embers, or possibly ignite nearby ground fuels.
  • It must be fully self-contained (heat source enclosed and no exposed flame) and never left unattended when in use.
  • Appliances that are not fully self-contained, such as braziers, are not permitted.
  • All appliances, materials and burnt fuel must be removed from the recreation area on your departure.

On the spot fines of $806 can be issued to people who light fires during a fire prohibition.

Campfires are permitted at Poverty Point camping area and at nearby Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area unless in accordance with all local directions for that area.

For details on the difference between a Queensland Fire and Emergency Services (QFES) total fire ban and a QPWS fire prohibition and approved cooking appliances visit the DES Camp fires and cooking web page.

QPWS thanks you for your cooperation while we implement this management change.

alerts.title: North West Island declaration of Special Activity Area (Sharks)
alerts.description: A new Special Activity Area has been declared at North West Island, Capricornia Cays National Park in accordance with Section 128 of the Marine Parks Regulation 2017.
alerts.details:
A new Special Activity Area has been declared at North West Island, Capricornia Cays National Park in accordance with Section 128 of the Marine Parks Regulation 2017.

This applies to the area surrounding North West Island on North West Island Reef to reduce the risk of humans interacting with sharks. Within the special activity area shown on the map (https://parks.des.qld.gov.au/parks/capricornia-cays/maps-resources)

You must not:

  • attract sharks by any means or methods to have a close interaction
  • process fish product
  • dump fish scraps
  • clean fish processing equipment.

Penalties may apply if you do any of these activities without prior permission or agreement under Section 132 of the Marine Parks Regulation 2017.

alerts.title: Dingo (Wongari) Seasonal Information - Breeding Season
alerts.description: Following the autumn mating season, many female wongari (dingoes) will be pregnant. Gestation takes about 9 weeks and litters of 110 pups (normally 46) are born and cared for (whelped) during the winter months. Once new-born pups arrive, their parents may be aggressive. They need to find food for themselves and their pups. Remember give dingoes space, Kgari is their place.
alerts.details:
Following the autumn mating season, many female wongari (dingoes) will be pregnant. Gestation takes about 9 weeks and litters of 110 pups (normally 46) are born and cared for (whelped) during the winter months. Once new-born pups arrive, their parents may be aggressive. They need to find food for themselves and their pups. Remember give dingoes space, Kgari is their place.

Visitors, tour operators and residents are advised to Be Dingo-safe! on K’gari. It is recommended that families with young children camp in fenced QPWS camping areas at Lake Boomanjin, Central Station, Dundubara, Waddy Point, and eastern beach fenced area (Wongai, One Tree Rocks, Cornwells, Eli), or at fenced private camping areas at Dilli Village or Cathedral Beach.

Let young wongari (dingoes) grow up wild - not reliant on handouts. Do not feed wongari (dingoes) or leave food available. Every time a wongari (dingo) receives food from people, its chance of survival is reduced.

Be dingo-safe! Visit https://parks.des.qld.gov.au/parks/kgari-fraser/about/wongari-dingoes/dingo-safe

  • Always stay close (within arm’s reach) of children and young teenagers.
  • Always walk in groups and carry a stick.
  • Camp in fenced areas where possible.
  • Do not run. Running or jogging can trigger a negative dingo interaction.
  • Never feed dingoes.
  • Lock up food stores and iceboxes (even on a boat).
  • Never store food or food containers in tents.

Report dingo encounters – email dingo.ranger@des.qld.gov.au, tell the nearest QPWS ranger, or phone (07) 4127 9150 – mobile phone charges may apply. Take note of location, vehicle registration, dingo ear tag colour, number and which ear and gender if available.

For further information about wongari (dingoes) on K’gari (Fraser Island) please visit https://parks.des.qld.gov.au/parks/kgari-fraser/about/wongari-dingoes

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

Please visit this park's page on the department's website for more park safety information.

alerts.title: George Point toilet removed due to erosion
alerts.description: George Point camping area on the southern coastline of Hinchinbrook Island National Park has been affected by severe erosion due to ongoing high tides over the past several years.
alerts.details:
George Point camping area on the southern coastline of Hinchinbrook Island National Park has been affected by severe erosion due to ongoing high tides over the past several years.

The camping area signage and infrastructure has been washed out and the toilet has been removed.

There is bush camping available nearby if needed by Thorsborne Trail hikers or sea kayakers. Space for camping is available under a large stand of trees approximately 150m to the northeast along the beach (prior to reaching the camping area when hiking from north to south). Please be aware there is no formal camping area and no toilet/pack rack. There is no boat-based camping available.

QPWS is currently reviewing options for the future of the site as part of the Thorsborne Trail Enhancement project.

alerts.title: Roadworks at Cunninghams Gap - temporary changes of walking tracks
alerts.description: Due to current and ongoing restoration works on the Cunningham Highway, walking tracks and visitor areas at the Cunninghams Gap section of Main Range National Park have been temporarily affected.
alerts.details:
Due to current and ongoing restoration works on the Cunningham Highway, walking tracks and visitor areas at the Cunninghams Gap section of Main Range National Park have been temporarily affected.

The following visitor areas have changed conditions:

  • All Cunningham Gap section walking tracks start from the West Gap Creek picnic area, via the Box Forest track. This includes Mount Cordeaux, Mount Mitchell, Bare Rock and the Rainforest circuit tracks. Walkers need to be aware of the extra 5km this will add to their intended walk. 
  • Access to The Crest carpark will be closed to all traffic from the Cunningham Highway.
  • Mount Mitchell track has been temporarily realigned and can be accessed from the western side of The Crest carpark via a temporary pedestrian crossing.
  • Visitors are encouraged to park at West Gap Creek picnic area 1.7km west from The Crest carpark.
  • Visitors are reminded that parking along the Cunningham Highway is prohibited. 

Road conditions and roadworks signage may vary depending on the stage of construction, and visitors are asked to follow all instructions and drive safely to road conditions.

For more information, please visit the Department of Transport and Main Roads website: Cunningham Highway (Ipswich – Warwick), 2020 Disaster Recovery Funding Arrangements reconstruction works | Department of Transport and Main Roads (tmr.qld.gov.au).

Please monitor Queensland Traffic for updated information regarding road and traffic conditions.

For your safety please slow down and observe all directions and signs.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

alerts.details:
Several low-lying camp sites adjacent to Pumicestone Passage on the western side of Bribie Island Recreation Area will be closed on a recurring basis throughout 2025 due to tidal inundation from forecast large high tides.

Affected camp sites include:

  • Lime Pocket camping area - All sites
  • Mission Point camping area - Sites 1-6 
  • Gallagher Point camping area - All sites
  • Poverty Creek camping area - Sites 4 & 5

Please note heights are taken from the Brisbane Bar tide chart. This is due to the changes in water flow caused by the northern breakaway section of Bribie Island.

On waterfront sites, campers should, where possible, consider placing tents and camping equipment back from the water’s edge to avoid any inundation from passing boats.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

alerts.title: Portable toilets are mandatory for Pelican Bay and Dorrigo South camping areas
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) have introduced mandatory portable toilet requirements at Pelican Bay and Dorrigo South camping areas (Inskip Point Recreation Area) from 01 June 2024. This initiative had been introduced to address high levels of bush toileting posing an unacceptable risk to the health and safety of campers and visitors and the areas natural environment.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) have introduced mandatory portable toilet requirements at Pelican Bay and Dorrigo South camping areas (Inskip Point Recreation Area) from 01 June 2024. This initiative had been introduced to address high levels of bush toileting posing an unacceptable risk to the health and safety of campers and visitors and the areas natural environment.

It is now an offence to camp at Pelican Bay and Dorrigo South camping areas without a portable toilet and penalties will apply. A minimum of one portable toilet per camping permit holder is required. Rangers will be on patrol to monitor compliance and educate campers about the benefits of using portable toilets.

Portable toilets must have a sealed waste holding tank and must be transportable and suitable for emptying into a portable toilet waste disposal facility. Bag and open bucket style toilets are not permitted. Images and further information are available here.

For your convenience, the Gympie Regional Council portable toilet waste disposal facility is located at Clarkson Drive, Rainbow Beach. Do not dispose of sanitary items, disposable nappies or toilet wipes into the toilet waste disposal facility as these items will block the system. Bag these items and take them home for disposal.

Do not empty your portable toilet waste into any toilets or general waste facilities in the recreation area as it creates a risk to human health and on-the-spot fines apply.

QPWS thanks you for your support and cooperation during this management change.

Note: This is a permanent management change for Pelican Bay and Dorrigo South camping areas. 

Please visit this park's page on the department's website for more park safety information.

alerts.title: Poison canisters washing up on Southeast Queensland beaches
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) is warning visitors of the potential dangers posed by toxic canisters washing up on Queensland beaches.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) is warning visitors of the potential dangers posed by toxic canisters washing up on Queensland beaches.

Since February 2012, emergency services have received reports from the public of small unlabelled canisters washing up on Australian beaches. QPWS continue to receive reports of these canisters washing up on beaches at K’gari, Mulgumpin (Moreton Island) and Minjerribah (North Stradbroke Island).

The canisters contain a rat poison known as ‘aluminium phosphide’, a white to grey solid which is hazardous to humans.

When the canister is opened, the powder reacts with moisture in the air to release phosphine gas, which is also highly toxic to humans. The gas has a strong odour that can smell like garlic, rotting fish or urine, but it can quickly dull the sense of smell.

Exposure can cause symptoms such as headaches, nausea, vomiting, difficulty breathing, dizziness, tightness of the chest, diarrhoea, fluid in the lungs, liver/kidney damage, and in severe cases death.

The gas is also flammable and can spontaneously ignite causing burns or small explosions.

The canisters are silver in colour and approximately 22 centimetres tall. They have a tapered top with a screw in lid.  Images of the canisters are available here.

Canisters should not be moved or opened, and any sightings should be reported to emergency services on Triple Zero (000).

alerts.title: Nearshore landslide Inskip Peninsula
alerts.description: Nearshore landslides and dynamic coastal activities are common within the Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area.
alerts.details:
Nearshore landslides and dynamic coastal activities are common within the Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area.

Recent high tides and steady shoreline retrogression has forced the requirement to remove a toilet facility within the Sarawak West camping area. As a result, camping capacity has been reduced in the area whilst the removal and relocation of the toilet facility takes place.

Campers and pedestrians should exercise caution and check access conditions as landslides can occur anywhere at any time. This is part of ongoing natural coastal erosion. 

For your safety and to avoid injuries:

  • Keep well back from sand cliffs and waters’ edge as unstable beach sand may collapse without warning.
  • Avoid swimming or wading around the landslide.
  • Be aware that submerged objects and strong underwater currents may be present.
  • Nearby trees or branches may fall at any time.
  • Supervise children at all times on the beach.
  • Observe all signage, barriers, and directions from Rangers, and do not enter closed areas.

Ensure compliance with any signage for your safety.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

alerts.title: Heightened dingo activity Lake McKenzie (Boorangoora)
alerts.description: QPWS Rangers on K'gari (Fraser Island) are urging visitors to be dingo safe at all times after recent high-risk dingo incidents at Lake McKenzie (Boorangoora). Visitors must only eat or prepare food in fenced picnic areas to reduce the risk of wongari habituation.
alerts.details:
QPWS Rangers on K'gari (Fraser Island) are urging visitors to be dingo safe at all times after recent high-risk dingo incidents at Lake McKenzie (Boorangoora). Visitors must only eat or prepare food in fenced picnic areas to reduce the risk of wongari habituation.

No food or drink (except water) to the lake shore or carpark. Penalties apply.

Remain vigilant of your surroundings at all times.

Be dingo-safe!
Visit https://parks.des.qld.gov.au/parks/kgari-fraser/about/wongari-dingoes/dingo-safe

  • NEVER feed dingoes.
  • Always stay within arm’s reach of children, even small teenagers.
  • Walk in groups and carry a stick.
  • Do not run. Running or jogging can trigger a negative dingo interaction.
  • Camp in fenced areas when possible.
  • Lock up food stores and iceboxes (even on a boat).
  • Never store food or food containers in tents.
  • Secure all rubbish, fish and bait.
  • No food to lakeshores.

Report dingo encounters – email dingo.ranger@des.qld.gov.au, tell the nearest QPWS Ranger, or phone (07) 4127 9150 – mobile phone charges may apply.
Take note of location, vehicle registration, dingo ear tag colour, number and which ear.

Your safety is our concern, but your responsibility.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

For your safety please be alert for nearby wildlife.

alerts.title: Thorsborne Trail changing to hiking seasons model
alerts.description: QPWS is taking steps to improve the experience for people booking camping permits for the Thorsborne Trail, by changing to a hiking seasons model.
alerts.details:
QPWS is taking steps to improve the experience for people booking camping permits for the Thorsborne Trail, by changing to a hiking seasons model.

Camping bookings for the Thorsborne Trail will be closed as of 24 January 2025 to allow for the transition to a new ‘booking seasons’ model. Existing permits up to 24 July 2025 will be transitioned to the new system and will not be impacted.

This means camping permits for the remainder of this year’s hiking season (24 July-31 December 2025) will be temporarily unavailable. Camping permits for the remainder of the 2025 hiking season will be released at 9am AEST on 1 April 2025. The standard annual seasonal closure period 1 January-28 February will remain in place to manage the increased risk of unsafe conditions at this time of year.

The Thorsborne Trail hiking seasons webpage contains information and updates about the changes including the camping permit release schedule. This page contains FAQs and information about how to be best prepared for the permit release. qld.gov.au/ThorsborneTrailHikingSeasons

alerts.title: Park Alert - Kgari Planned Burn Season 2025
alerts.description: The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) and Butchulla Aboriginal Corporation (BAC) rangers will be conducting planned burns within the Kgari (Fraser Island) section from 26th February 2024  August 31st 2025, weather permitting, as part of the annual hazard reduction/conservation management program for parks and forests.
alerts.details:
The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) and Butchulla Aboriginal Corporation (BAC) rangers will be conducting planned burns within the Kgari (Fraser Island) section from 26th February 2024 August 31st 2025, weather permitting, as part of the annual hazard reduction/conservation management program for parks and forests.

The aim of these burns is to reduce the volume of forest fuels and to create a mosaic pattern of burnt and unburnt areas.  This will help reduce the intensity of any subsequent wildfires and provide favourable conditions for natural forest regeneration.

As a result, smoke may be seen island-wide, including areas within Kingfisher Bay Resort Village, Dilli Village, Eurong resort & township, Dundubara, Orchid Beach township and Waddy Point.

Smoke can decrease visibility on the roads, so it is important that motorists drive safely to the conditions. Visitors and residents should close windows and doors and keep medications close by if suffering from a respiratory illness.

For more information, please call Eurong office of QPWS on (07) 4127 9128, Dundubara office of QPWS on (07) 4127 9138 or Waddy Point office of QPWS on (07) 14279190.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Your safety is our concern, but your responsibility.

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

alerts.title: PLanned Burns
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service will be undertaking planned burns within D'Aguilar National Park during appropriate weather opportunities over the coming months.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service will be undertaking planned burns within D'Aguilar National Park during appropriate weather opportunities over the coming months.

The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) conducts planned burns around the State to reduce the risk and intensity of bushfires and support a healthy environment.

As a result of the planned burn, smoke may be seen in the nearby areas.

Avoid driving through smoke where possible and be aware of firefighters working in the area.

These burns aim to mitigate the risk and intensity of bushfires and their potential impacts on communities, infrastructure, parks, and forests.

They are also vital in promoting ecological health, biodiversity, and the conservation of species and habitats.

Planned burns are highly weather-dependent, summer burns rely on high soil mositure to encourage natives to re-establish quickly.

Please follow the warnings and advise of any signs and any directions given by Rangers. 

If smoke affects you:

Stay indoors and close windows and doors; and
Keep respiratory medication close by.
Live air quality data, and information on smoke and dust health actions, can be found on the Queensland Government’s website https://www.qld.gov.au/environment/management/monitoring/air

You can stay updated with local QPWS fire activities by visiting Park Alerts or by following Qld Park Alerts on X (formerly known as Twitter).

Public safety is the highest consideration in all QPWS fire management activities. To find out more visit the Fire Management webpage.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

alerts.title: Notice of extended baiting program for feral pigs and foxes on Conway National Park, Dryander National Park, Dryander State Forest and Dryander Forest Reserve
alerts.description: The Department of the Environment, Tourism, Science and Innovation is undertaking a ground baiting program from 25 March 2025 to 25 March 2026. Manufactured baits will be used to control feral pigs and foxes on Conway National Park (Lot 43 on NPW1144 and Lot 1 on NPW1145), Dryander National Park (Lot 24 on AP19346), Dryander State Forest (Lot 432 on AP19346) and Dryander Forest Reserve (Lot 5 on AP19346). Notices will be placed at the Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service office at Jubilee Pocket and the Whitsunday Regional Council offices at Proserpine and Cannonvale for one week prior to each baiting event. These notices will remain in place for four weeks after baiting has finished. Notices will also be placed at the entrances of the Conway Circuit on Conway National Park and at Double Bay on Dryander National Park. A Park Alert will also be placed on the Department of Environment, Tourism, Science and Innovation website (www.detsi.qld.gov.au) for the same period. Dogs and other domestic animals are not allowed within protected areas. Steps must be taken to ensure domestic dogs do not gain access to the baits or poisoned animals. Neighbours should restrain dogs and other domestic animals during baiting programs. For more information, please contact the department on 13 QGOV (13 74 68).

alerts.title: Hazards impacting beach and driving conditions in Moreton Bay Coastal Parks
alerts.description: Recent weather events combined with abnormally high tides has caused severe beach erosion along exposed eastern beaches on Bribie Island, Mulgumpin (Moreton Island), Minjerribah (North Stradbroke Island) and South Stradbroke Island.
alerts.details:
Recent weather events combined with abnormally high tides has caused severe beach erosion along exposed eastern beaches on Bribie Island, Mulgumpin (Moreton Island), Minjerribah (North Stradbroke Island) and South Stradbroke Island.

Motorist should use caution when travelling along the open sections of beach and travel at a reduced speed to avoid hazards such as steep sand dunes, hidden banks, fallen trees, exposed coffee rock, WWII structures and large debris. The extreme tides have deposited large amounts of rubbish and potentially hazardous material. For your safety, please avoid any rubbish and prevent children from playing near it.

Beach travel is recommended one hour either side of low tide. Travel three hours either side of high tide should be avoided.

Driving over vegetated dunes is not permitted despite conditions. Fines apply for anyone driving or parking on vegetated dunes.

Lagoons are flowing across beaches and deep washouts are likely around them with conditions changing on a tidal basis. Check depth before crossing lagoons as fast flowing water and soft sand can make vehicle crossing dangerous.

Steep sand dunes along eroded beaches are very unstable and can collapse without warning. People have suffered serious injuries including death from being buried under collapsing dunes.  For yours and your families safety:

  • DO NOT climb or dig into sand dunes.

  • Avoid standing, sitting or parking your vehicle at the base of dunes.

  • NEVER allow children to play on or dig into dunes.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

The Main Beach camping area will be partially re-opened from Saturday 12 April 2025.  There will be reduced capacity which may have an impact on existing bookings.

Main Beach camping area capacity will be reduced for a period of time to allow for the sand to recover, before safe access can be reinstated to the affected sites.

Observe all signage, barriers and directions from Rangers and do not enter closed areas.

For enquiries and camping bookings at Main Beach, please visit Minjerribah Camping on www.minjerribahcamping.com.au.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

alerts.title: Temporary visitor facility closures and changes to access: Dubuji, Cape Tribulation section Daintree National Park (CYPAL)
alerts.description: From Friday 11 April to Sunday 30 November 2025 (dates inclusive), construction works for a new Indigenous Cultural Tourism Centre will be undertaken at Dubuji, Cape Tribulation. To allow contractors to complete this work, closures to some visitor facilities and changes to access will be necessary.
alerts.details:
From Friday 11 April to Sunday 30 November 2025 (dates inclusive), construction works for a new Indigenous Cultural Tourism Centre will be undertaken at Dubuji, Cape Tribulation. To allow contractors to complete this work, closures to some visitor facilities and changes to access will be necessary.

During this period all wheelchair accessible facilities and access points will be temporarily closed. Alternative accessible amenities are located opposite the Turtle Rock Café next to the playground (Wenden’s Wonderland), a short drive away.

Please see below for further details of impacted visitor facilities: 

Dubuji Boardwalk

  • The main access will be closed to the public
  • The boardwalk can be accessed via a link from Myall Beach track and completed as a return walk

Dubuji amenity block

  • Closed to the public
  • Visitors are asked to use alternative amenity block situated next to the playground (Wenden’s Wonderland) located to the North via a 200m walking track from the Dubuji car park.

Dubuji day-use area

  • Open
  • Parking spaces for buses will be reduced

Myall Beach

  • Access possible via the Dubuji day-use area

For your safety, obey all safety and directional signs and do not enter the construction site.

alerts.title: Planned burn - Tolderodden Conservation Park
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service will be undertaking planned burns in a section within Tolderodden Conservation Park during appropriate weather opportunities over the coming months.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service will be undertaking planned burns in a section within Tolderodden Conservation Park during appropriate weather opportunities over the coming months.

The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) conducts planned burns around the State to reduce the risk and intensity of bushfires and support a healthy environment.

As a result of the planned burn, smoke may be seen in the nearby areas.

Avoid driving through smoke where possible and be aware of firefighters working in the area.

These burns aim to mitigate the risk and intensity of bushfires and their potential impacts on communities, infrastructure, parks, and forests.

They are also vital in promoting ecological health, biodiversity, and the conservation of species and habitats.

Planned burns are highly weather-dependent, summer burns rely on high soil mositure to encourage natives to re-establish quickly.

Please follow the warnings and advise of any signs and any directions given by Rangers. 

If smoke affects you:

Stay indoors and close windows and doors; and
Keep respiratory medication close by.
Live air quality data, and information on smoke and dust health actions, can be found on the Queensland Government’s website https://www.qld.gov.au/environment/management/monitoring/air

You can stay updated with local QPWS fire activities by visiting Park Alerts or by following Qld Park Alerts.

Public safety is the highest consideration in all QPWS fire management activities. To find out more visit the Fire Management webpage.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

 

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

alerts.title: Eli Creek Exposed Sand Dunes
alerts.description: Exposed sand dunes and sand cliffs at Eli creek are unstable and collapse without warning, causing serious injury or death.
alerts.details:
Exposed sand dunes and sand cliffs at Eli creek are unstable and collapse without warning, causing serious injury or death.

Access to the sand cliffs is prohibited.

For your safety and to avoid injury:

  • Never climb or dig into sand dunes or sand cliffs.
  • Do not dig deep holes that may collapse. 
  • Do not jump, slide or dive into the creek.
  • Supervise children within arm’s reach at all times.

 

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

Please visit this park's page on the department's website for more park safety information.

alerts.title: Eurimbula National Park - Planned Burn Season 2025
alerts.description: The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will be conducting planned burns within Eurimbula National Park from 22nd of April 2025  August 31st 2025, weather permitting, as part of the annual hazard reduction/conservation management program for parks and forests.
alerts.details:
The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will be conducting planned burns within Eurimbula National Park from 22nd of April 2025 August 31st 2025, weather permitting, as part of the annual hazard reduction/conservation management program for parks and forests.

The aim of these burns is to reduce the volume of forest fuels and to create a mosaic pattern of burnt and unburnt areas.  This will help reduce the intensity of any subsequent wildfires and provide favourable conditions for natural forest regeneration.

As a result, smoke may be seen in the vicinity of Eurimbula NP including campgrounds and day-use areas, and within townships of Agnes Water, Captain Creek and Turkey Beach. 

Smoke can decrease visibility on the roads, so it is important that motorists drive safely to the conditions. Visitors and residents should close windows and doors and keep medications close by if suffering from a respiratory illness.

For more information, please call QPWS Agnes Water office on 0429 633 770. 

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

alerts.title: Cassowary safety message: Murray Falls section, Girramay National Park
alerts.description: Visitors are advised:
alerts.details:
Visitors are advised:

  • While cassowaries are fascinating, they are also potentially dangerous.
  • Please ensure all food, scraps and rubbish is secured and not accessible to cassowaries.  Extra vigilance is required around mealtimes.
  • Allowing cassowaries to connect human campsites with food is dangerous to camping area users and may lead to illness, injury, and deaths of birds.
  • Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service rangers are regularly visiting the park to provide education to camping area users regarding the cassowary behaviour and ensuring potential food sources are isolated.

alerts.title: Planned Burn Season
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will conduct planned burn operations on Magnetic Island National Park from May to September as part of the annual hazard reduction and conservation management program for parks and forests.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will conduct planned burn operations on Magnetic Island National Park from May to September as part of the annual hazard reduction and conservation management program for parks and forests.

Planned burns are vital in promoting ecological health, biodiversity, and the conservation of species and habitats.

They also aim to mitigate the risk and intensity of bushfires and their potential impacts on communities, infrastructure, parks, and forests.

Planned burns are highly weather-dependent, generally requiring milder conditions and minimal wind.

Before any planned burn is undertaken, local stakeholders, and nearby communities will be informed. Check Park Alerts for up to date information about QPWS planned burns.

Smoke may be seen coming from the island at times throughout the season. Smoke can decrease visibility on the roads and on the water, so it is important that motorists and vessel masters drive safely to the conditions.

Please observe all signage, barriers, and directions from Rangers.

For more information, please call the QPWS Magnetic Island office on (07) 4778 5378.

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

alerts.title: New waste transfer stations for Great Sandy National Park, Cooloola Recreation Area
alerts.description: Starting mid-May 2025, Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will be establishing new waste transfer stations for Great Sandy National Park, Cooloola Recreation Area.
alerts.details:
Starting mid-May 2025, Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will be establishing new waste transfer stations for Great Sandy National Park, Cooloola Recreation Area.

New waste stations will be located at the portable toilet waste facility site at:

  • Beach Road, 2nd Cutting, Noosa North Shore
  • Freshwater Road, off Rainbow Beach Road

There will be a transition period until late June 2025, with a limited number of bins remaining on the beach. During this transition period, campers are encouraged to dispose of their waste at the new waste transfer stations.

From 1 July 2025, all visitors to Great Sandy National Park, Cooloola Recreation Area including Teewah Beach, Freshwater and Double Island Point will be required to securely store and transport their waste to the new waste transfer stations. When storing and transporting your waste, ensure it is in sealed containers to prevent negative interactions with wildlife.

Waste bins will also be removed from Dorrigo South camping area at Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area. Bins will continue to be available for Inskip campers at Sarawak West, M.V. Sarawak, M.V. Beagle, M.V. Natone and S.S. Dorrigo camping areas. No bins are available at Pelican Bay camping area, but campers can use bins located at other Inskip camping areas.

For more information click new waste transfer station flier. 

Please visit this park's page on the department's website for more park safety information.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

alerts.title: Planned Burn Season: Fitzroy Island National Park
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will conduct Planned Burn Operations on Fitzroy Island National Park from May to September as part of the annual hazard reduction and conservation management program for parks and forests.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will conduct Planned Burn Operations on Fitzroy Island National Park from May to September as part of the annual hazard reduction and conservation management program for parks and forests.

Planned burns are vital in promoting ecological health, biodiversity, and the conservation of species and habitats.

They also aim to mitigate the risk and intensity of bushfires and their potential impacts on communities, infrastructure, parks, and forests.

Planned burns are highly dependent on weather conditions, typically requiring mild and stable weather conditions within a limited window of opportunity. As a result, these operations may be scheduled and carried out with little advance notice. 

Before any planned burn is undertaken local stakeholders and communities will be informed. Please be aware that some park facilities such as walking tracks may be closed to safely conduct the planned burn program. Check Park Alerts for up-to-date information about QPWS planned burns.

Smoke may be seen coming from the island at times throughout the season. Smoke can decrease visibility on the roads and on the water, so it is important that motorists and vessel masters drive safely to the conditions.

Please observe all signage, barriers, and directions from Rangers.

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

alerts.title: Planned burn for Parklands Conservation Park
alerts.description: The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) conducts planned burns on parks and forests to support a healthy environment and reduce the risk and intensity of bushfires. QPWS will conduct a planned burn in Parklands Conservation Park between Tuesday 27 May and Friday 31 July, 2025, weather permitting. As a result of the planned burn, smoke may be seen in nearby areas including Bli Bli and Nambour areas.
alerts.details:
The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) conducts planned burns on parks and forests to support a healthy environment and reduce the risk and intensity of bushfires. QPWS will conduct a planned burn in Parklands Conservation Park between Tuesday 27 May and Friday 31 July, 2025, weather permitting. As a result of the planned burn, smoke may be seen in nearby areas including Bli Bli and Nambour areas.

If visiting Parklands Conservation Park observe all signs, barriers, and directions from QPWS Rangers and never enter closed areas. 

Some sections of mountain bike trails and fire management trails will be closed during the burn period and reopened when safe.

Avoid driving through smoke where possible and be aware of firefighters working in the area.

Planned burns are vital in promoting ecological health, biodiversity, and the conservation of species and habitats.

They also aim to mitigate the risk and intensity of bushfires and their potential impacts on communi-ties, infrastructure, parks, and forests.

Planned burns are highly weather-dependent, generally requiring milder conditions and minimal wind.

These same weather conditions can also allow smoke to accumulate and linger until weather conditions change and winds assist in dispersing the smoke.

If smoke affects you:

  • Stay indoors and close windows and doors
  • Keep respiratory medication close by

Public safety is the highest consideration in all QPWS fire management activities. To find out more visit the Fire management webpage.

Live air quality data, and information on smoke and dust health actions, can be found on the Queensland Government’s website:

https://www.qld.gov.au/environment/management/monitoring/air

You can stay updated with local QPWS fire activities by visiting Park Alerts or by following Qld Park Alerts on X (formerly known as Twitter).
 

Facilities will reopen when conditions are considered safe.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

alerts.title: Open with caution: Munga-Thirri National Park
alerts.description: The QAA Line in Munga-Thirri National Park is open with caution. Detour markers have been placed on the QAA Line track to make the crossing possible. To protect and natural and cultural values of the national park (and your safety), it is important to stay on the marked QAA Line. All other tracks in Munga-Thirri National Park are currently inaccessible.
alerts.details:
The QAA Line in Munga-Thirri National Park is open with caution. Detour markers have been placed on the QAA Line track to make the crossing possible. To protect and natural and cultural values of the national park (and your safety), it is important to stay on the marked QAA Line. All other tracks in Munga-Thirri National Park are currently inaccessible.

Due to the current track detours in place on the QAA Line you must allow extra time and carry additional fuel to make the crossing. Ensure you have enough water and other supplies for the journey.

Camping is only permitted with 100 meters of the QAA Line and camping permits are required. There is no designated camping area or facilities.

Remember to plan and prepare well for the journey, help can be many days away. Munga-Thirri National Park and the Simpson Desert is remote and isolated —hot weather, unexpected rain and potential vehicle breakdowns all require that you plan carefully. You must be totally self-sufficient and prepared for all emergencies. For more information read Visiting Munga-Thirri safely.

Remember to check Park Alerts for Munga-Thirri National Park on the department's website for the latest information on access, conditions and closures.

For your safety please slow down and observe all directions and signs.

For your safety please use caution whilst visiting the park.

Stay up to date with weather forecasts, conditions and warnings.

alerts.title: Planned burning activities: Wooroonooran National Park, Mount Peter

alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife (QPWS) will be conducting planned burns (weather permitting) from Tuesday 10 June 2025 to Sunday 31 August 2025, as part of the fire management program for Wooroonooran National Park.

QPWS Rangers may be working along roadsides and throughout the community of Pyramid Estate.

For your safety and the safety of authorities, please slow down and observe all directions and signs. 

Visitors are advised that smoke may be seen in the vicinity of Gordonale, Edmonton, Goldsborough and the Atherton Tablelands. Persons with respiratory or other health problems should seek medical advice on mitigating the effects of smoke inhalation. 

Planned burns are vital in promoting ecological health, biodiversity, and the conservation of species and habitats. They also aim to mitigate the risk and intensity of bushfires and their potential impacts on communities, infrastructure, parks, and forests. 

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

Machinery operators have restricted/limited vision of walkers, runners and MTB riders approaching, especially from behind. alerts.title: Beach camping zone 9  Diray and Carree CLOSED
alerts.description: Beach camping zone 9 (Diray and Carree) is temporarily closed till 31 October 2025. This temporary closure is required due to severe erosion and fallen trees caused by large tides and ocean swell resulting in a reduction of accessible camp sites within the zone.
alerts.details:
Beach camping zone 9 (Diray and Carree) is temporarily closed till 31 October 2025. This temporary closure is required due to severe erosion and fallen trees caused by large tides and ocean swell resulting in a reduction of accessible camp sites within the zone.

All permits for Beach camping zone 9 (Diray and Carree) are suspended for the duration of the closure. If you have an existing booking please cancel and request a refund online for your existing Queensland National Parks camping or vehicle access booking/s  parks.desi.qld.gov.au/camping/how-to-make-a-booking/cancel-a-camping-booking

Alternate camping areas may be available in Beach camping Zone 8 (Marloo, Ocean Lake and Duling).

Travel to Sandy Cape is not advised as access is limited by fallen trees, exposed rock and erosion between Sandy Cape and Ngkala Rocks. Travel time is limited even on lowest expected low tides.

Rangers will continue to monitor the conditions and reopen the camping zone when deemed safe. 

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

alerts.title: Ngkala Rocks to Sandy Cape Beach Conditions
alerts.description: Exposed rock, sand erosion and fallen trees, between Ngkala Rocks and Sandy Cape have resulted in sections of beach becoming impassable. Return day travel to Sandy Cape is not advised due to risk of being stranded between low tides.
alerts.details:
Exposed rock, sand erosion and fallen trees, between Ngkala Rocks and Sandy Cape have resulted in sections of beach becoming impassable. Return day travel to Sandy Cape is not advised due to risk of being stranded between low tides.

The following areas are closed for recovery:

  • South Ngkala Rocks vehicle bypass (access past Ngkala Rocks only via beach on low tide) 
  • Beach camping zone 9 (Diray and Carree)

Motorists are advised to exercise caution at all times, plan ahead by checking tide times and only travel around the lowest expected low tide, if safe to do so. Drivers should slow down, stop and check access conditions before deciding if it is safe to traverse.

Be prepared:
- Always advise someone of intended trip itinerary
- Consider alternative communication devices as mobile reception is limited
- Carry sufficient drinking water in case you are delayed or stranded due to tides.

Visitors are reminded, camping where not permitted and driving over vegetated dunes pose a serious threat to the environment and nesting species such as turtles and shorebirds.

Your safety is our concern, but your responsibility.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

alerts.title: Partial reopening from 4 July: Lawn Hill Gorge section: Boodjamulla National Park (Aboriginal Land)
alerts.description: The Boodjamulla Co-operative Management Council (BCMC) is pleased to announce the staged re-opening of Lawn Hill Gorge section of Boodjamulla National Park (Aboriginal Land) will begin from Friday, 4 July 2025. This follows the significant flooding events of 2023 and 2024.
alerts.details:
The Boodjamulla Co-operative Management Council (BCMC) is pleased to announce the staged re-opening of Lawn Hill Gorge section of Boodjamulla National Park (Aboriginal Land) will begin from Friday, 4 July 2025. This follows the significant flooding events of 2023 and 2024.

Staged reopening

Visitor access will be restored in stages as rebuilding efforts progress.

From Friday 4 July 2025, the following visitor opportunities will be available at the Lawn Hill Gorge section of Boodjamulla National Park (Aboriginal Land):

  • Constance Range walking track
  • Lawn Hill Creek – for swimming and watercraft (one way in/one way out)
  • Camp site at Lawn Hill Gorge (with toilet facilities) – available only to authorised commercial tour operators initially.

Additional opportunities will become available from October 2025 as part of the staged plan. This includes:

  • Tent and camper trailer camping (bookings will be able to be made 14 days prior to re-opening).
  • Additional walking tracks.

Please check this park alert for updates on the reopening schedule.

For your safety

The flooding events have altered the look and feel of the gorge, but it remains a stunning and culturally significant place. While the area is regenerating, your safety is our top priority. Please note the following:

  • Construction zones: Some areas remain active construction sites and are closed to visitors. Signs, bunting and fences will mark these zones. Please follow all signage and directions from Rangers or on-site personnel.
  • Watercraft and swimming areas: Entry to Lawn Hill Creek is one way in and one way out. You must exit from the same location you entered.
  • Swimming distances and fitness: There are no shaded areas or stopping points between the entry point and Indarri Falls. Visitors should carefully assess their swimming ability and stamina before entering the water.
  • Limited shade: Shade is currently limited on land and in the water. Plan your visit carefully – bring at least 2 litres of drinking water per person per day, and wear a hat, long-sleeved shirt and covered shoes. Carry a first-aid kit and aim to explore during the cooler parts of the day.
  • Remote location: Lawn Hill Gorge is remote, and Rangers may not always be available. Visitors must be self-sufficient, responsible for your own safety, and prepared for emergencies.
  • Emergency contacts: For emergencies, call Triple Zero (000). Consider carrying a satellite phone or personal locator beacon (PLB).

The Boodjamulla Cooperative Management Council (i.e. the Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service and Waanyi People) thank the local community and stakeholders for their patience and support while work continues to safely restore and rebuild flood-damaged facilities and infrastructure.

The southern sections of Boodjamulla National Park (Aboriginal Land)—Riversleigh D Site (part of the Australian Fossil Mammal Sites World Heritage Area) and Miyumba camping area—remain fully open for visitors.

alerts.details:

Aircraft will be operating in the area during this period.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will be conducting aerial planned burning activities in Daintree National Park (CYPAL), Mount Lewis National Park, Mount Windsor National Park, Mowbray National Park and Ngalba-Bulal National Park (CYPAL) on Wednesday 25 June 2025. Aircraft will be operating in the area during this period.

The sections included in this planned burning activity are:

  • Daintree National Park (CYPAL) - Daintree west, Creb Track area (burning will occur away from the road corridor and will not affect any road users). Visitor facilities within Daintree National Park (CYPAL) will remain open.
  • Mt Lewis National Park - Windmill Creek
  • Mowbray National Park - Mowbray Falls

Most fire activity is expected to self-extinguish each evening, however some fire may remain active and smoke visible for 2 to 3 days following ignition. QPWS will monitor fire activity until it is out.

Burns will continue in the area as weather and seasonal conditions allow over coming weeks and months.

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

Planned burns are vital in promoting ecological health, biodiversity, and the conservation of species and habitats.

They also aim to mitigate the risk and intensity of bushfires and their potential impacts on communities, infrastructure, parks, and forests.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

alerts.title: Planned Burn for Conondale National Park
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will be conducting a planned burn (weather permitting) from 26/6/2025 to 27/6/2025 as part of the fire management program for Conondale National Park.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will be conducting a planned burn (weather permitting) from 26/6/2025 to 27/6/2025 as part of the fire management program for Conondale National Park.

Firefighters and machinery may be working along roadsides and walking tracks in the vicinity of Sunday Creek Road and the Conondale Great Walk between Tallowood walkers camp and Summer Falls walkers camp. For your safety and the safety of firefighters, please slow down and observe all directions and signs.

During the planned burn some sections of the Great Walk will be closed between Sunday Creek Road and Summer Falls walkers camp, detours and signage will be installed for bush walkers. 

·Smoke may be seen in the vicinity of Sunday Creek Road and Summer Falls Walkers Camp. Persons with respiratory or other health problems should seek medical advice on mitigating the effects of smoke inhalation.

 

 

 

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Due to the changed conditions the visitor experience may be affected.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

alerts.title: Planned burn in Gheebulum Kunungai (Moreton Island) National Park
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) and joint management partners Quandamooka Yoolooburrabee Aboriginal Corporation (QYAC) and Rural Fire Service Queensland will be conducting a planned burn in Gheebulum Kunungai (Moreton Island) National Park between 26 June 2025 and 27 June 2025, weather permitting.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) and joint management partners Quandamooka Yoolooburrabee Aboriginal Corporation (QYAC) and Rural Fire Service Queensland will be conducting a planned burn in Gheebulum Kunungai (Moreton Island) National Park between 26 June 2025 and 27 June 2025, weather permitting.

Cowan Cowan Bypass will be temporarily closed during the planned burn. A detour will be in place with short delays expected. Motorists are requested to show patience and follow all road closure signage and traffic controller directions.

Smoke may be seen in the vicinity of the western side of the island around the Cowan Cowan township. Smoke can decrease visibility on the roads, so it is important that motorists drive safely to the conditions.

Persons with respiratory or other health problems should seek medical advice on mitigating the effects of smoke inhalation.

Planned burns are vital in promoting ecological health, biodiversity, and the conservation of species and habitats. They also aim to mitigate the risk and intensity of bushfires and their potential impacts on communities, infrastructure, parks, and forests.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

For your safety please obey all fire restrictions.

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

alerts.title: Severe weather damage and shoreline retrogression - M.V. Natone camping area
alerts.description: As a result of severe weather damage and steady shoreline retrogression, M.V. Natone camping area at Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area is temporarily closed for visitor safety.
alerts.details:
As a result of severe weather damage and steady shoreline retrogression, M.V. Natone camping area at Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area is temporarily closed for visitor safety.

A Geotechnical assessment and report is being prepared to manage risks associated with coastal processes and campground safety for visitors. 

Alternative camping areas within the Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area are available. 

Observe all signage, barriers, and directions from rangers, and do not enter closed areas. All permits for closed areas are suspended for the duration of the closure. 

QPWS thanks you for your support and cooperation.
